ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: not nearly enough time for questions.spectacular line-up of guest speakers, perfectly orchestrated course, except too often it was a 2.5 hour lecture each week. there has to be time for intra-class discussion, and there almost never was. Professor should do a little less speaking and a little more questioning.we were DESPERATE to talk to each other all semester. ive never been in a class where i learned so little about my classmates despite good camaraderie and in general a great course.

Despite the fact that the course didn't feel particularly rigorous, this course was great for me. I learned a lot more than I thought I was learning over the course of the semester. This course is essential for all those learning to make change in the world.
An outstanding collection of readings. (I wish that more courses relied on journalism for their readings, as this course did, rather than academic articles.)
It wasn't the best class for me, but it was an amazing class that would be great for others.
By far, this has been the most useful course I have taken to date at F&ES. It is not focused on studying problems, but instead with solving them. In addition, this was my favorite F&ES course.

Fantastic course. This is what I thought FES would be like. Strategy, history, conspiracy. This course has it all. I loved the guest lecturers, and Prof. Northrops brilliant exposition and dialogue with them. The assignments were very useful and targeted. The readings were a a bit on and off. Some were fantastic, others felt like filler. I would have liked some more rigorous academic work and exploration of social change theory, as well as some more rigorous thinking on tactics and strategy. But it was all there, in a sort of bottom up kind of inductive reasoning way.
Amazing course. So practically focused and well-run.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: guest speakers were brilliant
Learning the ins and outs of campaigning!!

This course was extremely inspiring and an excellent window into how campaigns actually develop and win. I learned many great practical tools and am sure this class will help me in the future. I highly recommend this course.

This course discusses topics that aren't covered in other classes. Beyond the nuts and bolts of how to run good campaigns--vital for anyone who needs to convince anyone of anything, basically--this course really dives into motivation, ethics, morality, tactics, the environmental movement, etc. It's refreshing to have long discussions about these topics and helped me think about why I'm at FES and what I want to accomplish with my career.

Michael is wonderful. It's so refreshing to take a course with an instructor who is a practitioner, rather than an academic/scholar. Excellent guest speakers, the material felt relevant and important, and our discussions were very grounded in reality/actual on the ground experience. This was a wonderful class. Thank you, Michael!

Helped me achieve a solid understanding of how environmental campaigns actually function â more pragmatic than some other FES courses. Acquired incredibly useful, applicable knowledge in this course that you can't acquire in other classes. Also, it was just nice to hear about some success stories!
Amazing and candid campaign speakers.
The community it created and Michael's real-world perspective
The guest speakers and examinations of case studies of successful cases
This course was excellent in every aspect: the readings, guest lectures, instructor, and assignments.
The variety of speakers, the reading, the amazing professor and TA's.
People, inspiring speakers, the sense of its possible and the power of collective action and good strategy. trainings were really fun.

This course is a masterfully orchestrated tour of successful environmental campaigns, mostly in the U.S. Rather than the downers we normally hear about, this course goes over campaigns that succeeded against all odds to make a huge difference in the world.

This is the best course I've taked at FES. It's inspiring and motivating. I am currently applying the readings and materials I put together for the class for my internship. I wish there were more courses like this at FES.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: time management- wheres the discussion?

I dislike reading responses that we never discuss; it just seems like a lot of busy work for no reason. I'd be totally okay with weekly reading responses if we actually received feedback from Michael and/or if we discussed them in class.
The reading is kind of irrelevant.
Not anything that I can think of. I think the class size was perfect this year.

I think the week-to-week reflection assignments don't serve much of a purpose. Yeah, they get us to think a little about the readings, but they're never really followed up on in any meaningful way. Right now, they just feel like work for work's sake. I think the weekly writing assignments could be better integrated, or replaced with more meaningful assignments.
The reading list could have been more substantail; though, the light reading load was appreciated!
More focus on things other than climate change.
None. There is nothing to improve.
more rigorous readings, less reading whole books, especially when they were a bit filler-ey.maybe an assignment organizing a trial campaign?
None!
There is nothing I would change about the course.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I'd like a little more tying all the lessons from the visiting speakers together.
Most class sessions were a well-integrated mix of lecture and discussion... we flowed pretty loosely between the two.
no need to improve. Michael Northrop is an amazing professor.
The lectures were extremely integral to this course. They were useful, surprising and inspirational.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: campaiging/advocacy is something i'm really into, and is my professional background.

I now see that I could do the work of campaigning. This course helped me see that there is good work I could do after graduating. That was something I had been doubting. It has been great for me to see that.

I intend to work for environmental NGOs, and the skills I learned in this class â media strategies, campaign structure, power mapping, etc â will be extremely useful in actually achieving my organization's goals. We talk a lot in this school about what needs to be done, but comparatively little about how to do it.
Looking back, I'm not sure it does. It was an amazing class tho.

Campaigns are important for getting a message across to big audiences. This course took a stab at looking at some campaigns. I would like to spend more time on campaigns other than climate change or oil. Social movements is particularly exciting when there is a clear need for refocusing priorities of the masses.
Before this class, I was interested in policy, but from a more passive standpoint. This class made me realize that I want to work on the forefront of environmental campaigns.

This was counterpoint to my scientific studies, but was just so inspiring. I felt really grateful to have access to michael and these amazing speakers and TAS. sandy, bonnie, and tom were just brilliant.

I do energy and climate issues, and aim to work in energy in the private sector. I don't see myself going into campaigning after graduation (though I have lots of past work in advocacy), but this was a fascinating course given my interests.

This course has changed the direction of my research and my interested. It's helped me find my passion: campaigns and advocacy. My summer internship/research is a direct result of this course. I lament that there are not any other courses at FES to compliment this one. I am looking into creating a course that can compliment it.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: dunno but thank goodness i did- probably my favorite class of the semester.
I wanted to understand how to make actual change in the world.
I thought it would be interesting, as I'm interested in communications.
Heard it was a good course, and the course topic is highly relevant to the work that we do at F&ES.
Again, I wanted to learn some practical skills, and I also wanted to get fired up as I leave this place and head out into the world.
Sounded like fun and it was fun.
To learn about how to create a successful campaign.
My curriculum needed a course on how to apply academic learning and practice to policymaking and the most effective and productive methods through which to work with communities and create campaigns.
My interest in environmental policy.
to get pumped! to get optimistic! to fight the doom and gloom and all the greedy motherfuckers spoiling the earth for profit!
See Q17
I wanted to be inspired. It worked (only one other course in my first year at FES inspired me).

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Not really; it was the same message every week with every guest lecturer.
Yes.
Exceeded them.
Yes, absolutely!
Yes, definitely! Learned about all sorts of interesting campaigns whose lessons will be applicable to whatever I want to do.
In part, but it was not the best choice for me.
Sort of. There is a need to reframe the way most of americans view the natural world and I would have liked to see more of these campaigns.
Yes!

This class far exceeded my expectations. It was compelling and instrumental in directing the trajectory of my career. In addition, I received my summer internship as a direct result of the research I was conducting for the term paper.
yes. again, more rigor and social theory would have been welcome.
Exceeded my expectations
I have the tools to plan a campaign. This exceeds my expectations.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I don't know if you'd call it a "work group," but the out-of-class seminars run by Tom Owens were fantastic.
Had at least one group campaign training session, which was okay. Advantages: my teammates had good ideas. Disadvantages: they weren't much fun to work with.
Teamwork was good.
Very helpful campaign planning simulations!
too rushed, but awesome activity. an assignment planning a campaign with a small group over a longer time period in a real world context would have been cool.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: yeah take it! definitely! especially if you arebrimming to fight for the environment or a specific issue or whatever.
It's only mediocre
Take it. Definitely. But maybe just audit it.
Definitely take it. It's fantastic. It's also a bit lighter load, so good to take if you need to balance your semester.
Do it!
Make sure you actually read Bury the Chains!
If you want to get into the nitty gritty of hardball campaigning, this class is a must. If not, it is still interesting and fun.
Do it! Michael is a great professor with a ton of interesting contacts and a broad perspective on what works and what doesn't in Environmental Campaign planning.
Read! I always regretted not making more time to read.
Take this course!

This class should be mandatory for all F&ESstudents, regardless of whether their focus is on policy or not. In the end, we are all trying to effect change in some shape or form and this class is the most direct way to effect policy.
take good notes.
This is one of the gems of FES. Take it if you get the chance!
Do it! It's the best course atFES.
Definitely take it.
